title: Part A(i,ii)
stimulusHtml:
(i)

1 point is earned : For a correct equation for the circuit containing all the required variables

ε =( r+R ) I

(ii)

Slope-intercept method

The above equation can be re-arranged to express 1/ I as a function of R

1 I = R ε + r ε

The emf is the inverse of the slope of the graph.

1 point is earned : For using the slope of the line to determine the emf.

1 point is earned : For using data from the best-fit line

For example:

S l o p e = 1 ε = ( 0.8 − 0.2 ) ( 1 / A ) ( 45 − 10 ) Ω = 0.6 35 V

ε = 35/0.6 V = 58.3V
1 point is earned : For using the intercept of the line to determine the battery resistance

Intercept = r /ε

For example, reading an intercept of 0.03(1/A)

r = (intercept)ε = (0.03(1/A))(58.3 V) = 1.75 Ω

Alternate Solution:

For using two points to set up two equations

For using data from the best-fit line

For solving for r and ε

title: Part B (i,ii)
stimulusHtml:
(i)




1 point is earned: For a design that allows the potential difference across resistor X to be varied

1 point is earned: For an ammeter and a voltmeter connected correctly to measure current and potential difference for resistor X

(ii)

1 point is earned: For a correct method for varying the potential difference across resistor X.

For the example circuit shown above, use each of the resistors in turn as resistor R.

1 point is earned: For indicating appropriate measurements for each trial

For example, for each value of resistor R, measure the potential difference and current for resistor X.

(iii)

1 point is earned: For indicating appropriate quantities to graph

For the example described above, graph current as a function of potential difference.

1 point is earned: For indicating an appropriate property of the graph

For the example described above, the graph would be linear if resistor X was ohmic.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned: For correctly indicating ‘yes’ or ‘no’ consistent with circuit drawn, and some reasonable attempt at a correct justification

For the example described above, the correct response is ‘no’.

1 point is earned: For a correct justification

For the example described above, the measured values are those for only resistor X. Since the point is to change the resistance external to X, it does not matter how or why it changes. As long as the measurements are the quantities for X by itself the data is legitimate
